Greetings,

I thought so at first also, when trying to address this before I
posted, but there's no setup or tear down to do in my tests.
The problem (in that example code) is with the
  New TestSuite(MyTestCase.class);
This suite is then returned, and the Class object provided is then
instantiated multiple times, once for each test* method in
MyTestCase.  There's still no way of associating state with the
individual MyTestCase objects, between test* methods.

What I want is more 'new TestSuite(new MyTestCase());', and then
to have EVERY test on MyTestCase called with just that object.

If you look at the TestSuite source, the only way it has to add a
test is through addTestMethod.  addTestMethod relies on calling
createTest.  createTest constructs a new instance, every time, of
the provided class.

I admit, I don't understand the logic in this, and am looking for
help.  It's not that I don't want my setup() and teardown()s called
every time (they're empty for me), it's that there is important state
to preserve BETWEEN tests, in order to make a logical breakdown
of tests that test correctly despite an unpredictable server state.
(I.e. I can't assume the message that gets put to the server is
always going to be numbered '1', and hardcode that in the rest
of my tests.)

What's the design rationale for making this (apparently)
impossible, or is this just a use case that was overlooked?

--  Morgan Schweers
